issues.title: [Feature Request] camel/configs/vllm_config.py need extra_body support for structured output
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

# ========= Copyright 2023-2024 @ CAMEL-AI.org. All Rights Reserved. =========
# Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License");
# you may not use this file except in compliance with the License.
# You may obtain a copy of the License at
#
#     http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0
#
# Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software
# distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
# WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
# See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
# limitations under the License.
# ========= Copyright 2023-2024 @ CAMEL-AI.org. All Rights Reserved. =========
from __future__ import annotations

from typing import Optional, Sequence, Union

from pydantic import Field

from camel.configs.base_config import BaseConfig


# flake8: noqa: E501
class VLLMConfig(BaseConfig):
    r"""Defines the parameters for generating chat completions using the
    OpenAI API.

    Reference: https://docs.vllm.ai/en/latest/serving/openai_compatible_server.html

    Args:
        temperature (float, optional): Sampling temperature to use, between
            :obj:`0` and :obj:`2`. Higher values make the output more random,
            while lower values make it more focused and deterministic.
            (default: :obj:`None`)
        top_p (float, optional): An alternative to sampling with temperature,
            called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of
            the tokens with top_p probability mass. So :obj:`0.1` means only
            the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.
            (default: :obj:`None`)
        n (int, optional): How many chat completion choices to generate for
            each input message. (default: :obj:`None`)
        response_format (object, optional): An object specifying the format
            that the model must output. Compatible with GPT-4 Turbo and all
            GPT-3.5 Turbo models newer than gpt-3.5-turbo-1106. Setting to
            {"type": "json_object"} enables JSON mode, which guarantees the
            message the model generates is valid JSON. Important: when using
            JSON mode, you must also instruct the model to produce JSON
            yourself via a system or user message. Without this, the model
            may generate an unending stream of whitespace until the generation
            reaches the token limit, resulting in a long-running and seemingly
            "stuck" request. Also note that the message content may be
            partially cut off if finish_reason="length", which indicates the
            generation exceeded max_tokens or the conversation exceeded the
            max context length.
        stream (bool, optional): If True, partial message deltas will be sent
            as data-only server-sent events as they become available.
            (default: :obj:`None`)
        stop (str or list, optional): Up to :obj:`4` sequences where the API
            will stop generating further tokens. (default: :obj:`None`)
        max_tokens (int, optional): The maximum number of tokens to generate
            in the chat completion. The total length of input tokens and
            generated tokens is limited by the model's context length.
            (default: :obj:`None`)
        presence_penalty (float, optional): Number between :obj:`-2.0` and
            :obj:`2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether
            they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood
            to talk about new topics. See more information about frequency and
            presence penalties. (default: :obj:`None`)
        frequency_penalty (float, optional): Number between :obj:`-2.0` and
            :obj:`2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their
            existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's
            likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim. See more information
            about frequency and presence penalties. (default: :obj:`None`)
        logit_bias (dict, optional): Modify the likelihood of specified tokens
            appearing in the completion. Accepts a json object that maps tokens
            (specified by their token ID in the tokenizer) to an associated
            bias value from :obj:`-100` to :obj:`100`. Mathematically, the bias
            is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling.
            The exact effect will vary per model, but values between:obj:` -1`
            and :obj:`1` should decrease or increase likelihood of selection;
            values like :obj:`-100` or :obj:`100` should result in a ban or
            exclusive selection of the relevant token. (default: :obj:`None`)
        user (str, optional): A unique identifier representing your end-user,
            which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse.
            (default: :obj:`None`)
        logprobs: Whether to return log probabilities of the output tokens or
            not. If true, returns the log probabilities of each output token
            returned in the `logits` of `message`. (default: :obj:`None`)
        top_logprobs: An integer between 0 and 20 specifying the number of
            most likely tokens to return at each token position, each with an
            associated log probability. `logprobs` must be set to `true` if
            this parameter is used. (default: :obj:`None`)
    """

    temperature: Optional[float] = None  # openai default: 1.0
    top_p: Optional[float] = None
    n: Optional[int] = None
    stream: Optional[bool] = None
    stop: Optional[Union[str, Sequence[str]]] = None
    max_tokens: Optional[int] = None
    presence_penalty: Optional[float] = None
    response_format: Optional[dict] = None
    frequency_penalty: Optional[float] = None
    logit_bias: dict = Field(default_factory=dict)
    user: Optional[str] = None
    logprobs: Optional[bool] = None
    top_logprobs: Optional[int] = None


VLLM_API_PARAMS = {param for param in VLLMConfig.model_fields.keys()}



### Solution

Please add the following to `camel.configs.vllm_config` to support structured output when deploying vLLM locally:
```
class VLLMConfig(BaseConfig):
    **extra_body: dict  # add extra_body support**
```

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [Question] Automating Report Generation with Camel Framework Using Natural Language Rules and Excel Templates
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have read the documentation <https://camel-ai.github.io/camel/camel.html>.
- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Questions

Hi, can the Camel framework achieve the following requirement: Given an Excel template and data retrieval rules based on natural language, can the framework use a large model to generate data retrieval SQL statements (possibly multiple SQLs) based on this information, execute the SQL, and then populate the generated data into the template to form the final report? If feasible, please provide a brief description of the implementation approach.

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

<!-- Please outline the motivation for the proposal.
Is your feature request related to a problem? E.g., "I'm always frustrated when [...]".
If this is related to another issue, please link here too. -->
Hello Team,

Some enterprise users of Azure OpenAI are required to include additional HTTP headers‚Äîsuch as custom correlation IDs or subscription keys‚Äîwhen making requests to the endpoint. Currently, the camel-ai does not support a straightforward way to customize or inject these headers.

I propose adding support for an extra_headers parameter in the client call to allow users to specify additional headers as needed.

**Example Use Case:**
```
completion = client.chat.completions.create(
    model="gpt-35-turbo",
    messages=[
        {
            "role": "user",
            "content": "Hello OpenAI",
        },
    ],
    extra_headers={
        'x-correlation-id': str(uuid.uuid4()),
        'x-subscription-key': os.getenv("SUBSCRIPTION_KEY")
    }
)
```
Thank you for your time and for the great work on this project!


### Solution

_No response_

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [Feature Request] Support for Streaming Responses in the step() Method of RolePlaying Society
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

## Description

Currently, the `step()` method in the RolePlaying society only returns results after a complete round of conversation has finished (with both assistant and user messages completed). This creates a noticeable delay in interactive applications, especially when dealing with longer responses.

Would it be possible to enhance the `step()` method to support streaming responses? This would allow applications to receive and display assistant and user messages as they are being generated, rather than waiting for the entire exchange to complete.

## Potential Benefits

1. Improved user experience with real-time message generation
2. Better integration with web applications that require responsive UI

## Proposed Solution

Perhaps the `step()` method could be modified to:
- Return a generator that yields message fragments as they are produced
- Provide an alternative `astep_stream()` async method for modern applications
- Include event markers to indicate when a full message is complete

## Questions

- Is this change feasible without breaking existing implementations?
- Would adding this feature require significant refactoring of the current architecture?
- Are there any performance considerations that might make this challenging?

I believe this enhancement would greatly improve the responsiveness and usability of applications built with CAMEL. Thank you for considering this feature request.



### Solution

_No response_

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: Camel dependencies conflicts
issues.body:
Currently, I am building a new project based on Camel, however, in `camel[all]` version, it restricts `numpy~1.26`. This seem to strict since some package uses `numpy >= 2`. I wonder if we can relax this constrain.

Attached are error when trying to build my project:

√ó No solution found when resolving dependencies for split ‚îÇ (python_full_version >= '3.13' and sys_platform == 'darwin'):
‚ï∞‚îÄ‚ñ∂ Because only the following versions of numpy{python_full_version >= '3.13'} are available: numpy{python_full_version >= '3.13'}<=2.1.0 numpy{python_full_version >= '3.13'}==2.1.1 numpy{python_full_version >= '3.13'}==2.1.2 numpy{python_full_version >= '3.13'}==2.1.3 numpy{python_full_version >= '3.13'}==2.2.0 numpy{python_full_version >= '3.13'}==2.2.1 numpy{python_full_version >= '3.13'}==2.2.2 numpy{python_full_version >= '3.13'}==2.2.3 numpy{python_full_version >= '3.13'}==2.2.4 numpy{python_full_version >= '3.13'}==2.2.5 and magika>=0.6.1 depends on numpy{python_full_version >= '3.13'}>=2.1.0, we can conclude that magika>=0.6.1 depends on numpy>=2.1.0. And because only the following versions of magika are available: magika<=0.6.1 magika==0.6.2 we can conclude that magika>=0.6.1 depends on numpy>=2.1.0. And because markitdown==0.1.1 depends on magika>=0.6.1 and camel-ai[all]==0.2.58 depends on markitdown==0.1.1, we can conclude that camel-ai[all]==0.2.58 depends on numpy>=2.1.0. And because camel-ai[all]==0.2.58 depends on numpy>=1.26,<2.dev0 and only camel-ai[all]<=0.2.58 is available, we can conclude that camel-ai[all]>=0.2.58 cannot be used. And because your project depends on camel-ai[all]>=0.2.58 and your project requires camel-toolkits-mcp[dev], we can conclude that your project's requirements are unsatisfiable. hint: Pre-releases are available for numpy in the requested range (e.g., 2.2.0rc1), but pre-releases weren't enabled (try: --prerelease=allow) hint: magika was requested with a pre-release marker (e.g., all of: magika>0.6.1,<0.6.2 magika>0.6.2,<0.7.dev0 ), but pre-releases weren't enabled (try: --prerelease=allow)

issues.title: [Feature Request] Add integration tests (Or at least a simple automated check CAMEL works with minimal dependencies)
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

To ensure that CAMEL always works out of the box for projects using it or where it is part of a dependency graph, it is important that the optional dependencies are really optional and that CAMEL is known to work outside the context of the global dependencies of developers' machines or with all optionals installed.

For example, right now this will fail:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/camel-ai/camel
cd camel
pip install uv
uv venv .venv --python=3.10
source .venv/bin/activate
uv pip install -e "."
python examples/tasks/task_generation.py
```
With these errors:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/caelum/PycharmProjects/camel_min/examples/tasks/task_generation.py", line 15, in <module>
    from camel.agents import ChatAgent
  File "/Users/caelum/PycharmProjects/camel_min/camel/agents/__init__.py", line 15, in <module>
    from .chat_agent import ChatAgent
  File "/Users/caelum/PycharmProjects/camel_min/camel/agents/chat_agent.py", line 41, in <module>
    from camel.agents._types import ModelResponse, ToolCallRequest
  File "/Users/caelum/PycharmProjects/camel_min/camel/agents/_types.py", line 19, in <module>
    from camel.messages import BaseMessage
  File "/Users/caelum/PycharmProjects/camel_min/camel/messages/__init__.py", line 47, in <module>
    from .base import BaseMessage  # noqa: E402
  File "/Users/caelum/PycharmProjects/camel_min/camel/messages/base.py", line 20, in <module>
    import numpy as np
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'numpy'
```
with `uv add numpy`, or `pip install .` the next error is related to 'PIL'.
(I expect the situation is the same if you're just installing CAMEL via pip install from pypi but correct me if I'm wrong)

## Upstream breakages (future work ideas)
It is also possible that CAMEL's dependencies can break CAMEL without any changes being made to CAMEL. I think this is an unavoidable hazard of having so many dependencies and being a python project (until Python allows deep version locking with multiple versions of same libraries and eliminates an over dependence on native libraries).

But the hazard can be greatly reduced with some steps, here are some ideas:
* Feature flags / increasing the number of optional dependencies. e.g. whenever a third party SDK is used for a loader or tool, it might better become an optional dependency, so that if it breaks everything then it can only impact actual users of that tool
* Move tools and loaders to MCP servers and let network boundaries handle this
* Frequently re-testing with a dependency graph output saved, so that when a breaking upstream change is detected, the requirement version ranges can be re-specified to avoid the breaking change 

### Solution

I think it would be very valuable to run those above commands as part of the merge checks.

### Alternatives

See future work. I expect those to be harder but if for some reason this isn't viable they can yield some of the same benefits of doing this.

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [Feature Request] The more operations the browser_toolkit performs, the lower the accuracy of the web agent model.
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

When I use DeepSeek v3 as the web agent model for the browser_toolkit, as the number of browser operations increases, the model's system prompt grows larger, and the model fails to provide correct answers. Operations that have already been successfully completed are deemed unfinished.


### Solution

Reset the history message of web_agent. Important history information is already included in the history field in observe_prompt.

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [Feature Request] Implement Terminal Agent for Executing Terminal Commands
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

An agent capable of executing terminal-related commands, such as inspecting local files or managing system processes. Adding a Terminal Agent will enable the system to perform a wide range of terminal operations dynamically.

## Proposed Solution:
Develop a Terminal Agent capable of executing shell commands securely and returning the results. This agent should:

Handle common file system operations (e.g., list, read, and modify files).

Support command execution with appropriate permission control.

Return structured output to facilitate further processing.

## Key Tasks:
Define the Terminal Agent with a secure command execution interface.

Implement basic file system and process management commands.

Add safeguards to prevent unauthorized or unsafe command execution.

Integrate the Terminal Agent into the workforce framework.

Test the Terminal Agent with various command scenarios.

### Solution

_No response_

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

(+1 or comment there if it has.) - [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new). ### Motivation Hi Team, I'm learning to integrate a custom MCP server into OWL. After setting up the environment variables, I ran: ```bash python examples/run.py "Write a hello world python file and save it locally, then execute the python file" ``` While the script runs, I encountered an issue: the agent cannot execute the Python file because `CodeExecutionToolkit` only supports Python code execution , despite `SubprocessInterpreter` having bash support. Code pointer: 1. CodeExecutionToolkit https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/blob/6c5d76c57683e9fdc947c68f0856232c904dfd10/camel/toolkits/code_execution.py#L98-L112 2. SubprocessInterpreter's unused bash capability: https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/blob/6c5d76c57683e9fdc947c68f0856232c904dfd10/camel/interpreters/subprocess_interpreter.py#L268 ### Solution _No response_ ### Alternatives _No response_ ### Additional context _No response_

issues.title: [BUG] Workers return ```tool_code... instead of calling the tool correctly
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have read the documentation <https://camel-ai.github.io/camel/camel.html>.
- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### What version of camel are you using?

0.2.37

### System information

The library was installed through Owl, which was cloned by git.
Environment:
- Python 3.10.16 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Dec  5 2024, 14:20:01) [Clang 18.1.8 ] darwin
- Camel 0.2.37, owl 0.0.1
- Apple Silicon mac

### Problem description

Gemini 2.0 flash often returns malformed tool_code instead of correctly calling the tool, like so
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d8bca639-c6ed-44c9-96d0-4c786f921374)
Perhaps this is more of a Gemini issue than a Camel issue in the immediate, but I believe Camel should have robust fallbacks for models with poor tool-calling support, perhaps in a predefined JSON response format.

Browser_use handles this really well, for instance, by requesting a specific JSON response format from the model as a fallback when tool calling is not supported.

### Reproducible example code

```python
    workforce.add_single_agent_worker(
        "composer",
        worker=ChatAgent(
            BaseMessage.make_assistant_message(role_name="composer", content="""You are an author dedicated to composing a comprehensive report that includes all relevant details, facts, and supporting data, at the end of all research and development. Ensure that all key points are covered, including background information, analysis, and conclusions. Keep the language sharp and concise. Avoid unnecessary elaboration or repetition. Organize the report in a clear, structured format with headings, bullet points, or sections as appropriate, but if instructed to write an essay, use prose only. Prioritize clarity and precision, delivering the necessary information without excess or fluff. Once you are finished composing, save all your results to ./report.md using the write_to_file tool."""), 
            model=models["composer"],
            tools=[*ThinkingToolkit().get_tools(), *FileWriteToolkit(output_dir="./").get_tools()]
        )
    )
```

```python
        "composer": ModelFactory.create(
            model_platform=ModelPlatformType.GEMINI,
            model_type=ModelType.GEMINI_2_0_PRO_EXP,
            model_config_dict={"temperature": 0},
        ),
```

Command line: `python ../examples/run.py`

### Traceback

```pytb

```

### Expected behavior

Accurate tool calls, especially for Gemini, or a fallback response format aimed at less capable models

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [BUG]  in camel/__init__.py, __all__ incorrectly lists 'camel' which is not defined or imported
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have read the documentation <https://camel-ai.github.io/camel/camel.html>.
- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### What version of camel are you using?

0.2.57

### System information

See Below.

### Problem description


When executing:

```python
from camel import *
```

The following error occurs:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: module 'camel' has no attribute 'camel'
```

This is because in `camel/__init__.py`,  `__all__` list includes `'camel'`, but the module does not define or import any symbol named `camel`.

```python
__all__ = [
    '__version__',
    'camel',  # <- This entry is invalid
    'disable_logging',
    'enable_logging',
    'set_log_level',
]
```
## Suggested Fix
Remove `'camel'` from `__all__`?

### Reproducible example code

See above

```pytb

```

issues.title: [Feature Request] Improve `BaseToolkit` MCP server launch interface
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

Currently, the MCP server is started using:

```
toolkit.mcp.run(args.mode)
```

This interface exposes internal implementation details (`mcp`) and breaks encapsulation, making the API feel awkward and harder to maintain or refactor.

Suggested Improvements
To provide a cleaner, more intuitive interface, we can encapsulate with a direct method:
```
toolkit.run_mcp_server(mode=args.mode)
```

Todo:

- [ ] Add `run_mcp_server` to `BaseToolkit`
- [ ] Update documentation and usage examples

issues.title: [BUG] Gemini models do not call any tools when response format is set
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have read the documentation <https://camel-ai.github.io/camel/camel.html>.
- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### What version of camel are you using?

0.2.56

### System information

library was installed through pip, I used a minimal example to recreate this


### Problem description

After a while I found this code in gemini_model.py, inside _run, line 127. 

        if response_format:
            return self._request_parse(messages, response_format)

And as you can see here we are missing tools, therefore when I require the model to produce a structured output it fails to use the tools I've provided which is very troublesome for my code. E.g. I cannot use response format and tools at the same time

My code replies heavily on response format to be correct. I think it's very straightforward problem which exists in your code. Is this a limitation from google?

Link to the source code
https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/blob/8d7405f25c391681dbc97b54dd18409610829a77/camel/models/gemini_model.py#L127

### Reproducible example code


The following snippet is minimal reproduceble
```
model = ModelFactory.create(
    api_key=os.getenv("API_KEY_GEMINI"),
    model_platform=ModelPlatformType.GEMINI,
    model_type=ModelType.GEMINI_2_0_FLASH_THINKING,
)
```
```
agent = ChatAgent(
    model=model,
    tools=[any tools you have available],
)
agent.step(query, response_format = SomePydanticModel)
```


### Traceback

```pytb

```

### Expected behavior

When calling with tools and response format, it should invoke the tools. 

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [Feature Request] WhyAzureOpenAI models does not include reasoning ones (e.g., o3-mini)?
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

Currently, the definition of function `is_azure_openai` of class `ModelType` is like

```Python
def is_azure_openai(self) -> bool:
    r"""Returns whether this type of models is an OpenAI-released model
    from Azure.
    """
    return self in {
        ModelType.GPT_3_5_TURBO,
        ModelType.GPT_4,
        ModelType.GPT_4_TURBO,
        ModelType.GPT_4O,
        ModelType.GPT_4O_MINI,
    }
```

I wonder why the list is too limited to include models that are actually supported by Azure AI, including but not limited to `O3_MINI`?

Btw, is it really necessary to check whether user-specified model platform matches model type? I did not see it.

### Solution

_No response_

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [Feature Request] Integrate Google's Gemini Embedding Model (`gemini-embedding-exp-03-07`)
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

I'd like to propose integrating Google's new Gemini Embedding model (gemini-embedding-exp-03-07) into Camel. According to Google's recent [announcement](https://developers.googleblog.com/en/gemini-embedding-text-model-now-available-gemini-api/), this model:

- Surpasses their previous state-of-the-art model (text-embedding-004)
- Achieves the top rank on the Massive Text Embedding Benchmark (MTEB) Multilingual leaderboard with a mean score of 68.32 (+5.81 over the next competitor)
- Offers longer input token length
- Works effectively across diverse domains (finance, science, legal, search, etc.) without requiring extensive fine-tuning

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cb96b793-63e4-46af-ad78-99f91c38b52b)

This SOTA embedding model would significantly enhance Camel's text processing capabilities and provide users with more powerful semantic understanding options.

### Solution

According to the original camel design and the official embedding usage demo:

```python
from google import genai

client = genai.Client(api_key="GEMINI_API_KEY")

result = client.models.embed_content(
        model="gemini-embedding-exp-03-07",
        contents="How does alphafold work?",
)

print(result.embeddings)
```

I propose:

- Add a new file named `gemini_embedding` in `camel/embeddings` folder.
- Update the `class EmbeddingModelType` in `camel/types/enums.py` file.

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [BUG] OpenAI function tool schema validation error due to missing additionalProperties field
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have read the documentation <https://camel-ai.github.io/camel/camel.html>.
- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### What version of camel are you using?

0.2.45

### System information

Python version : 3.10
Camel version : 0.2.45

### Problem description

When using the CAMEL framework with OpenAI's function calling feature, the system throws a BadRequestError if object-type parameters in function schemas don't explicitly set additionalProperties: false. This causes failures when tools are registered and used.

**Error Message**
```
openai.BadRequestError: Error code: 400 - {'error': {'message': "Invalid schema for function 'search_documents': In context=('properties', 'body'), 'additionalProperties' is required to be supplied and to be false.", 'type': 'invalid_request_error', 'param': 'tools[6].function.parameters', 'code': 'invalid_function_parameters'}}
```



### Reproducible example code

The Python snippets:

```python

```

Command lines:

```bash

```

Extra dependencies:

```text

```

**Reproduction Steps**
- Define a mcp server in your local machine.
- Register this function tool with an OpenAI model / Azure OpenAI model.
- Attempt to use the tool in agentic conversation

**Current Behavior**
The framework allows to register all tolls with the language model for conversations, but OpenAI calls gets rejected these schemas with a 400 error during function calling.

**Expected Behavior**
The framework should ensure all object-type parameters in function schemas have additionalProperties: false set by default when not explicitly specified by developers.


### Traceback

```pytb
Error occurred while running society simulation: Unable to process messages: the only provided model did not run successfully. Error: Error code: 400 - {'error': {'message': "Invalid schema for function 'search_documents': In context=('properties', 'body'), 'additionalProperties' is required to be supplied and to be false.", 'type': 'invalid_request_error', 'param': 'tools[6].function.parameters', 'code': 'invalid_function_parameters'}}

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/path/to/site-packages/camel/agents/chat_agent.py", line 791, in _get_model_response
    response = self.model_backend.run(
  File "/path/to/site-packages/camel/models/model_manager.py", line 226, in run
    raise exc
  File "/path/to/site-packages/camel/models/model_manager.py", line 216, in run
    response = self.current_model.run(messages, response_format, tools)
  File "/path/to/site-packages/camel/models/base_model.py", line 50, in wrapped_run
    return original_run(self, messages, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/path/to/site-packages/camel/models/base_model.py", line 278, in run
    return self._run(messages, response_format, tools)
  File "/path/to/site-packages/camel/models/azure_openai_model.py", line 153, in _run
    return self._request_chat_completion(messages, tools)
  File "/path/to/site-packages/camel/models/azure_openai_model.py", line 194, in _request_chat_completion
    return self._client.chat.completions.create(
  File "/path/to/site-packages/openai/_utils/_utils.py", line 279, in wrapper
    return func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/path/to/site-packages/openai/resources/chat/completions/completions.py", line 929, in create
    return self._post(
  File "/path/to/site-packages/openai/_base_client.py", line 1276, in post
    return cast(ResponseT, self.request(cast_to, opts, stream=stream, stream_cls=stream_cls))
  File "/path/to/site-packages/openai/_base_client.py", line 949, in request
    return self._request(
  File "/path/to/site-packages/openai/_base_client.py", line 1057, in _request
    raise self._make_status_error_from_response(err.response) from None
openai.BadRequestError: Error code: 400 - {'error': {'message': "Invalid schema for function 'search_documents': In context=('properties', 'body'), 'additionalProperties' is required to be supplied and to be false.", 'type': 'invalid_request_error', 'param': 'tools[6].function.parameters', 'code': 'invalid_function_parameters'}}
```

### Expected behavior

Tool calls should be executed as expected.

### Additional context

_No response_
issues.author: shankarbhavani

comments.author: Wendong-Fan
comments.body: hey @shankarbhavani , which model platform you're using? I think OpenClient requires additionalProperties to be False, not sure whether you're using AzureOpenAI that could has different requirement?

comments.author: shankarbhavani
comments.body: I am using Azure OpenAI. But I have seen similar issues in OpenAI Agentic SDK where Custom MCP servers by default doesn't provide this field, so they handled it at SDK level to add this. Check this out << https://github.com/openai/openai-agents-python/issues/449

comments.author: Wendong-Fan
comments.body: hey @shankarbhavani , sorry for the late reply, this issue has been resolved in https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/commit/9746a8c108b57b20b420f279d8509ffe5596abec, you can customize the MCP schema whether to use "strict",  and the default value is set to `False` now

issues.title: [BUG] MCPToolkit did not exclude unsupported parameters in the OpenAI API when building the tool schema
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have read the documentation <https://camel-ai.github.io/camel/camel.html>.
- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### What version of camel are you using?

0.2.45

### System information

3.10.12 (main, Aug 16 2023, 15:12:12) [Clang 13.1.6 (clang-1316.0.21.2.5)] darwin
0.2.45


### Problem description

Some mcp services return tool parameters that include "default" 

https://github.com/tavily-ai/tavily-mcp/blob/main/src/index.ts#L106

However, the OpenAI API does not support parameters that include the default attribute.

> openai.BadRequestError: Error code: 400 - {'error': {'message': "Invalid schema for function 'tavily-search': In context=('properties', 'days'), 'default' is not permitted.", 'type': 'invalid_request_error', 'param': 'tools[0].function.parameters', 'code': 'invalid_function_parameters'}}


### Reproducible example code

The Python snippets:

```python
    mcp_toolkit = MCPToolkit(config_path=config_path) # camels toolkit to define mcp tools
    async with mcp_toolkit.connection() as toolkit:
        tools = toolkit.get_tools()
        sys_msg = (
            "You are a helpful assistant. Always use the provided external tools for filesystem operations "
            "Also remember to use the tools to answer questions about the filesystem. Always use the tools "
            "Make sure to keep the messages short and to the point so that tokens are not wasted. "
            "when asked, rather than relying on your internal knowledge. Ensure that your final answer does not "
            "end with any trailing whitespace."
        )
        model = ModelFactory.create(
            model_platform=ModelPlatformType.OPENAI,
            model_type=ModelType.GPT_4O_MINI,
            model_config_dict=ChatGPTConfig().as_dict(),
            # [Optional] the config for model
        )
        camel_agent = ChatAgent( # create agent with our mcp tools
            system_message=sys_msg,
            model=model,
            tools=tools,
        )
        camel_agent.reset() # reset after each loop
        camel_agent.memory.clear()
        await interactive_input_loop(camel_agent) # start the interactive loop
```

config_path

```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "tavily-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "tavily-mcp@0.1.4"],
      "env": {
        "TAVILY_API_KEY": "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"
      },
      "disabled": false,
      "autoApprove": []
    }
  }
}
```

### Traceback

```pytb

```

### Expected behavior

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [Feature Request] Solid model test including tool call & structured output
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

Different model platforms may have varying requirements for tool schemas and structured outputs. For example, the OpenAI beta client requires fields like stick, additionalProperties, and anyOf, which may not be supported by other platforms.

Our current unit tests use mocks and don't validate actual tool calls or structured outputs. To catch potential issues earlier, we should build more comprehensive tests that make real API requests. These tests don't need to run with every CI/CD cycle but should be available for deeper validation.

### Solution

_No response_

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: Support `str` like behaviour for `ModelPlatformType` like `ModelType` to simplify interface
issues.body:
The goal is to simplify interface to enable creating a `ChatAgent` with one line of code.

The currect interface for create a `ChatAgent` with a model is like this:
```
from camel.models import ModelFactory
from camel.types import ModelPlatformType, ModelType
from camel.agents import ChatAgent

# Define the model, here in this case we use gpt-4o-mini
model = ModelFactory.create(
    model_platform=ModelPlatformType.OPENAI,
    model_type=ModelType.GPT_4O_MINI,
)

# Initialize the agent
ChatAgent("You are a helpful assistant.", model=model)
```

By supporting `str` like behaviour for `ModelPlatformType` we can do:
```
from camel.models import ModelFactory
from camel.agents import ChatAgent

# Define the model, here in this case we use gpt-4o-mini
model = ModelFactory.create(
    model_platform="openai",
    model_type="gpt-4o-mini",
)

# Initialize the agent
ChatAgent("You are a helpful assistant.", model=model)
```

By creating `model` inside `ChatAgent` with differnt if-else conditions we can do:
```
from camel.agents import ChatAgent

# Initialize the agent with a `tuple`
ChatAgent("You are a helpful assistant.", model=("openai", "gpt-4o-mini"))

# Or just a `str` for model type. Try to find the corresponding `ModelPlatformType` or use default `ModelPlatformType`
ChatAgent("You are a helpful assistant.", model="gpt-4o-mini") 
```

Of course we can also support:
```
from camel.agents import ChatAgent
from camel.types import ModelPlatformType, ModelType

# Initialize the agent with a `tuple` of `enum`
ChatAgent("You are a helpful assistant.", model=(ModelPlatformType.OPENAI, ModelType.GPT_4O_MINI))

# Or just a `enum` for model type. Try to find the corresponding `ModelPlatformType` or use default `ModelPlatformType`
ChatAgent("You are a helpful assistant.", model=ModelType.GPT_4O_MINI) 
```
issues.author: lightaime

issues.title: [Feature Request] Add alternate method for handling API keys for the cookbooks
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)

### Motivation

<!-- Please outline the motivation for the proposal.
Is your feature request related to a problem? E.g., "I'm always frustrated when [...]".
If this is related to another issue, please link here too. -->

I am new to Camel and have been going through the cookbooks to get learn about both LLM agents and Camel's frameworks. However, the cookbooks require passing the API key upon prompt. For one, I don't have the API keys always available with me. Also, even when it is there, I got to copy paste it every time I use a different cookbook. 

Given this, it would be nice to add this little functionality to the cookbooks (or at least to the introductory ones).


### Solution

Since the cookbooks are geared for use in a Colab notebook, one could add their API keys to the secrets and then they could be accessed across notebooks, simplifying the exploration of the cookbooks.



### Alternatives

_No response_

issues.title: [Feature Request]  ReAct (Reasoning and Acting) Agent
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [X] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [X] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

Recent research results, in particular the paper of Shunyu Yao et al entitled' REACT: synergizing reasoning and acting in language models',  have demonstrated the possibility of combining verbal reasoning with interactive decision making in autonomous systems. The tight synergy between 'acting' and 'reasoning' allows humans to learn new tasks quickly and perform robust decision making. 


### Solution

Add an extra type named 'ReasoningType' to specify the categories of output system messages. 
'REASONING' -- the default reasoning type which only contains verbal messages produced by the language model; 
'ACT' --  messages that involve function calling procedure;
'REACT' -- A combination of reasoning and acting.

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [BUG] When running astep in ChatAgent, external tool call will be executed, instead of directly returning
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have read the documentation <https://camel-ai.github.io/camel/camel.html>.
- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### What version of camel are you using?

0.2.37

### System information

3.12.1 (v3.12.1:2305ca5144, Dec  7 2023, 17:23:39) [Clang 13.0.0 (clang-1300.0.29.30)] darwin
0.2.37


### Problem description

In ChatAgent astep function, when model decides to use a external tool, the expected behavior is directly return, but actually it will be executed.
The reason seems like missing an "else" after checking whether the tool is an external tool.
The behavior is step function is correct, where the "else" branch is present.

issues.title: [BUG] siliconflow model 500 error
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have read the documentation <https://camel-ai.github.io/camel/camel.html>.
- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### What version of camel are you using?

0.2.37

### System information

3.11.11 | packaged by Anaconda, Inc. | (main, Dec 11 2024, 16:34:19) [MSC v.1929 64 bit (AMD64)] win32
0.2.37

### Problem description

The model failed to run successfully when running `siliconflow_model_example.py`

### Reproducible example code

The Python snippets:

```python
class SiliconFlowConfig(BaseConfig):
    r"""Defines the parameters for generating chat completions using the
    SiliconFlow API.

    Args:
        temperature (float, optional): Determines the degree of randomness
            in the response. (default: :obj:`None`)
        top_p (float, optional): The top_p (nucleus) parameter is used to
            dynamically adjust the number of choices for each predicted token
            based on the cumulative probabilities. (default: :obj:`None`)
        n (int, optional): Number of generations to return.
            (default: :obj:`None`)
        response_format (object, optional): An object specifying the format
            that the model must output. (default: :obj:`None`)
        stream (bool, optional): If set, tokens are returned as Server-Sent
            Events as they are made available. (default: :obj:`None`)
        stop (str or list, optional): Up to :obj:`4` sequences where the API
            will stop generating further tokens. (default: :obj:`None`)
        max_tokens (int, optional): The maximum number of tokens to generate.
            (default: :obj:`None`)
        frequency_penalty (float, optional): Number between :obj:`-2.0` and
            :obj:`2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their
            existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's
            likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim. See more information
            about frequency and presence penalties. (default: :obj:`None`)
        tools (list[FunctionTool], optional): A list of tools the model may
            call. Currently, only functions are supported as a tool. Use this
            to provide a list of functions the model may generate JSON inputs
            for. A max of 128 functions are supported. (default: :obj:`None`)
    """

    temperature: Optional[float] = None
    top_p: Optional[float] = None
    n: Optional[int] = None
    stream: Optional[bool] = None
    stop: Optional[Union[str, Sequence[str]]] = None
    max_tokens: Optional[int] = None
    response_format: Optional[Union[Type[BaseModel], dict]] = None
    frequency_penalty: Optional[float] = None
```

Command lines:

```bash
> python -m examples.models.siliconflow_model_example
```

Extra dependencies:

```text

```

Steps to reproduce:

1.
2.
3.


### Traceback

```pytb
raise ModelProcessingError(
camel.models.model_manager.ModelProcessingError: Unable to process messages: the only provided model did not run successfully. Error: Error code: 500
```

### Expected behavior

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_
issues.author: zachysun

comments.body:
Please set `stream` as False and it works for me.

Or you can change the code implementation of class `SiliconFlowConfig`:

```python
stream: Optional[bool] = False
```

Additionally, I think it's a question of siliconflow's backend.

issues.title: [BUG] FewShotGenerator response_format using DataPoint is not accepted
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have read the documentation <https://camel-ai.github.io/camel/camel.html>.
- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### What version of camel are you using?

0.2.46

### System information

-

### Problem description

in DataPoint we defined
```
    # metadata: Optional[Dict[str, Any]] = Field(
    #     default=None, description="Additional metadata about the data point."
    # )
```

this Optional[Dict[str, Any]] type is not accepted when do structured out put in
```
                    agent_output = (
                        self.agent.step(prompt, response_format=DataPoint)
                        .msgs[0]
                        .parsed
                    )
```

### Reproducible example code

The Python snippets:

```python
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field

from camel.agents import ChatAgent
from camel.models import ModelFactory
from camel.types import ModelPlatformType, ModelType
from camel.datasets.models import DataPoint

# Define system message
assistant_sys_msg = "You are a helpful assistant."

model = ModelFactory.create(
    model_platform=ModelPlatformType.DEFAULT,
    model_type=ModelType.DEFAULT,
)

# Set agent
camel_agent = ChatAgent(assistant_sys_msg, model=model)


# Get response information
response = camel_agent.step("generate a joke", response_format=DataPoint)
print(response.msgs[0].content)

```


would get 
```
openai.BadRequestError: Error code: 400 - {'error': {'message': "Invalid schema for response_format 'DataPoint': In context=('properties', 'metadata', 'anyOf', '0'), 'additionalProperties' is required to be supplied and to be false.", 'type': 'invalid_request_error', 'param': 'response_format', 'code': None}}
```



### Traceback

```pytb

```

### Expected behavior

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [Feature Request] Polish Interface of data generation pipleline
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

The current datagen pipeline interface has usability issues that hinder efficiency:

File Path Dependency: Requiring file paths in initialization adds rigidity, complicating workflows with programmatically generated data.
Inconvenient Input Format: Expecting inputs as file paths instead of direct jsonl data creates unnecessary overhead.
Lack of Flexibility: The design limits adaptability and increases boilerplate code.

We need to redesign the interface to:
Support Direct Data Input: Allow inputs as jsonl strings or Python objects.
Streamline API: Align with best practices from projects like [Distilabel](https://github.com/argilla-io/distilabel) and [Curator](https://github.com/bespokelabsai/curator), emphasizing modularity and ease of use.

unified interface by adding `BaseDataGenPipeline` module

_No response_

issues.title: [Question] Does MinerU loader support local pdf files?
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have read the documentation <https://camel-ai.github.io/camel/camel.html>.
- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Questions

I want to use MinerU loader in CAMEL to load my local pdf files. Does it support that? Because I got the following error.

Here is my code:
```
from camel.loaders import MinerU

# Initialize the MinerU loader
loader = MinerU()

# Load a local PDF file
pdf_path = "/home/export/base/ycsc_wangbenyou/yangyz/online1/toby/Graph-Agent-Network/TwinMarket/czq/pdfs/report.pdf"
document = loader.batch_extract_urls(pdf_path)

# Now you can access the content of the PDF
content = document.content

# Print the content to verify it loaded correctly
print(content)
with open("output.txt", 'w') as f:
    f.write(content)
```

Here is the output:
```
‚óã ‚Üí python camelapi.py 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/export/base/ycsc_wangbenyou/yangyz/.conda/envs/camelai/lib/python3.10/site-packages/camel/loaders/mineru_extractor.py", line 135, in batch_extract_urls
    response.raise_for_status()
  File "/home/export/base/ycsc_wangbenyou/yangyz/.conda/envs/camelai/lib/python3.10/site-packages/requests/models.py", line 1024, in raise_for_status
    raise HTTPError(http_error_msg, response=self)
requests.exceptions.HTTPError: 400 Client Error: Bad Request for url: https://mineru.net/api/v4/extract/task/batch

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/online1/ycsc_wangbenyou/yangyz/toby/Graph-Agent-Network/TwinMarket/czq/camelapi.py", line 8, in <module>
    document = loader.batch_extract_urls(pdf_path)

issues.title: [BUG] ValueError: my_functionis not strict. Onlystrict function tools can be auto-parsed
issues.body: ### Required prerequisites - [x] I have read the documentation . - [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.) - [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new). ### What version of camel are you using? 0.2.42 ### System information 3.12.2 | packaged by Anaconda, Inc. | (main, Feb 27 2024, 12:57:28) [Clang 14.0.6 ] darwin 0.2.42 ### Problem description I encountered a critical issue when using camel in combination with mcp_toolkit and AzureOpenAIModel. Specifically, when attempting to run a tool function named my_function, the following error occurs: `ValueError: `my_function` is not strict. Only `strict` function tools can be auto-parsed` The AzureOpenAIModel fails to handle this tool due to a strictness requirement during auto-parsing. This breaks my task execution flow in the Workforce setup. The model fails to generate a response due to the tool not being marked as strict, despite it working under other model backends. ### Reproducible example code import asyncio from mcp.types import CallToolResult from camel.toolkits.mcp_toolkit import MCPToolkit, MCPClient import os from camel.tasks.task import Task from camel.agents import ChatAgent import json async def run_example(): mcp_client = MCPClient( command_or_url="http://127.0.0.1:8000/sse", ) await mcp_client.connect() mcp_toolkit = MCPToolkit(servers=[mcp_client]) vasp_tools = mcp_toolkit.get_tools() for tool in vasp_tools: print(json.dumps(tool.get_openai_tool_schema())) try: engineer_agent = ChatAgent( model=model, system_message="‰Ω†ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Â∑•Á®ãÂ∏àÔºåÊØèÊ¨°ÂØπËØùÂâçÂÖàÂ±ïÁ§∫‰Ω†Êúâ‰ªÄ‰πàÂ∑•ÂÖ∑„ÄÇË¥üË¥£ËøêË°åËÑöÊú¨ÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÂêëÂØºÂ∏àÊî∂Âà∞calcdirÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéËøêË°åcommit_vaspÂáΩÊï∞Ôºå‰πãÂêéËøîÂõû‰ªªÂä°Â∑≤Êèê‰∫§üéâ", tools=[*vasp_tools], output_language="zh-CN" ) # print(engineer_agent._get_full_tool_schemas()) check_agent = ChatAgent( model=model, system_message="‰Ω†ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂØºÂ∏àÔºåË¥üË¥£ÂêëÂ∑•Á®ãÂ∏àÂèëÈÄÅcalcdirÔºåcaldirÊòØSrBaFeO,Âπ∂ËÆ©‰ªñÊâßË°åcommit_vaspÂáΩÊï∞", output_language="zh-CN" ) workforce = Workforce('VASP‰ªøÁúüËÆ°ÁÆóÂõ¢Èòü', coordinator_agent_kwargs={"model": model,"output_language":"zh-CN"}, task_agent_kwargs={"model": model,"output_language":"zh-CN"}, new_worker_agent_kwargs={"model": model,"output_language":"zh-CN"} ) workforce.add_single_agent_worker( "Ë¥üË¥£Êèê‰∫§‰ªªÂä°ÁöÑÂ∑•Á®ãÂ∏à", worker=engineer_agent, ).add_single_agent_worker( "ÂëäËØâÂ∑•Á®ãÂ∏àcaldirÁöÑÂØºÂ∏à", worker=check_agent ) human_task = Task( content=( """ **‰ªªÂä°ÁõÆÊ†á**ÔºöÂØºÂ∏àÂëäËØâÂ∑•Á®ãÂ∏àcaldirÔºåÂ∑•Á®ãÂ∏àËøêË°åcommit_vaspÂáΩÊï∞„ÄÇ """ ), id='0', ) subtasks = workforce._decompose_task(human_task) task = workforce.process_task(human_task) except Exception as e: print(f"Error during agent execution: {e}") finally: await mcp_client.disconnect() if __name__ == "__main__": asyncio.run(run_example()) ### Traceback ```pytb ``` ### Expected behavior _No response_ ### Additional context

issues.title: [Feature Request] add medicine toolkit (verifier) for loong project
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

## Issue: Add Medicine Toolkit (vefivier) for Loong Project

### Background
We need to integrate a standardized medicine calculation toolkit (verifier) into the Loong project to support various medical calculation tasks.




### Solution

### Task Requirements

- **Rewrite the `medcalc_bench` tools:**
  - Include all tool functions from the existing `medcalc_bench`.
  - Add standardized docstrings to each tool function, clearly describing functionality, parameters, and return values.
  - Provide test cases and examples for each tool function to ensure usability and accuracy.
  - Fix existing errors within the current `medcalc_bench` implementation.
  - Adjust the directory structure of `medcalc_bench` clearly separating tool modules from core utility modules.

- **Create `medcalc_toolkit.py`:**
  - Implement standardized docstrings clearly outlining the purpose of each tool function.
  - Allow centralized access to all rewritten tools from the `medcalc_bench`.

- **Develop a Toolkit Example (`tool_example.py`):**
  - Showcase usage examples demonstrating how to invoke tool functions from `medcalc_toolkit`.
  - Include clear scenarios and explanatory comments.

### Acceptance Criteria
- `medcalc_toolkit.py` can successfully call all rewritten `medcalc_bench` tools.
- Each tool function has a clear, standardized docstring and effective test examples.
- The updated structure is clear and easy to maintain and extend.

### Next Steps
- Developers create a corresponding PR based on this issue and submit it for review.
- Team members perform code reviews and verify functionality.

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [Feature Request] Implement Learn-by-interact
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

Learn-by-interact: A Data-Centric Framework for Self-Adaptive Agents in Realistic Environments

Autonomous agents powered by large language models (LLMs) have the potential to enhance human capabilities, assisting with digital tasks from sending emails to performing data analysis. The abilities of existing LLMs at such tasks are often hindered by the lack of high-quality agent data from the corresponding environments they interact with. We propose Learn-by-interact, a data-centric framework to adapt LLM agents to any given environments without human annotations. Learn-by-interact synthesizes trajectories of agent-environment interactions based on documentations, and constructs instructions by summarizing or abstracting the interaction histories, a process called backward construction. We assess the quality of our synthetic data by using them in both training-based scenarios and training-free in-context learning (ICL), where we craft innovative retrieval approaches optimized for agents. Extensive experiments on SWE-bench, WebArena, OSWorld and Spider2-V spanning across realistic coding, web, and desktop environments show the effectiveness of Learn-by-interact in various downstream agentic tasks -- baseline results are improved by up to 12.2\% for ICL with Claude-3.5 and 19.5\% for training with Codestral-22B. We further demonstrate the critical role of backward construction, which provides up to 14.0\% improvement for training. Our ablation studies demonstrate the efficiency provided by our synthesized data in ICL and the superiority of our retrieval pipeline over alternative approaches like conventional retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). We expect that Learn-by-interact will serve as a foundation for agent data synthesis as LLMs are increasingly deployed at real-world environments.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2501.10893

### Solution

### Alternatives

issues.title: [Feature Request] Unify format of the docstring for all code
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [X] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

Currently there's some code doesn't follow the docstring standard, we need to review and polish

### Solution

Guideline for Writing Docstrings:

This guideline will help you write clear, concise, and structured docstrings for contributing to `CAMEL`.

1. Use the Triple-Quoted String with `r"""` (raw string)
Begin the docstring with `r"""` to indicate a raw docstring. This prevents any issues with special characters and ensures consistent formatting, especially in documentation tools like Sphinx.

2. Provide a Brief Class or Method Description
Start with a concise summary of the purpose and functionality, keeping each line under `79` characters. The summary should start from the first line without a linebreak:

```
r"""Class for managing conversations of CAMEL Chat Agents.
"""
```

3. Document the Args Section
Use the `Args`: section to document the constructor parameters, maintaining the `79`-character limit for each line. Break long descriptions into multiple lines if necessary, indenting continuation lines by `4` spaces. For each parameter, follow this structure:

Parameter name: The name of the parameter as it appears in the function signature.
`Type`: The type of the parameter (e.g., `int`, `str`, custom types like `BaseModelBackend`). If a parameter is optional, use the suffix , `optional`.
Description: A brief explanation of the parameter‚Äôs purpose.
Default value: If applicable, include the default value using the format `(default: :obj:<default_value>)`. Use `:obj:` to denote Python objects.
4. Explain Optional Parameters Clearly
For optional parameters, describe how the class behaves when the parameter is not provided. Keep each line under `79` characters, breaking longer descriptions into multiple lines.

5. Use `reST` Formatting for Links
When referring to objects, types, or classes (e.g., `BaseMessage`), use `reST` roles like `:obj:` for proper formatting and linking. Ensure that lines do not exceed `79` characters.

6. Provide Default Values Consistently
For parameters with default values, include them in parentheses at the end of the description. Keep the `(default: :obj:<default_value>)` format consistent throughout. Wrap long descriptions to avoid exceeding `79` characters.

7. Limit Line Length to `79` Characters
Ensure that all lines are limited to `79` characters for readability. Break long sentences or descriptions into multiple lines, and indent continuation lines by 4 spaces. This improves readability in text editors and follows Python's PEP 8 and PEP 257 guidelines.

8. Class Docstring of the Constructor (`__init__`)
To improve code hinting in editors like Visual Studio Code, include the constructor's docstring directly under the class definition. This ensures that code editors can display detailed hints.

```
class MyClass:
    r"""Class for managing conversations of CAMEL Chat Agents.

    Args:
        system_message (BaseMessage): The system message for the chat
            agent, used to initialize the conversation and provide context.
        model (BaseModelBackend, optional): The model backend to use for
            generating responses. If not provided, defaults to
            :obj:`OpenAIModel` with `GPT_4O_MINI`. 
            (default: :obj:`OpenAIModel` with `GPT_4O_MINI`)
        memory (AgentMemory, optional): The agent's memory for managing chat 
            messages. If `None`, a default :obj:`ChatHistoryMemory` will
            be used. (default: :obj:`None`)
        message_window_size (int, optional): The maximum number of previous 
            messages to include in the context window. If `None`, no 
            windowing is applied. (default: :obj:`None`)
        token_limit (int, optional): The maximum number of tokens allowed 
            in the context before pruning occurs. If `None`, the token 
            limit is automatically set by the backend model. 
            (default: :obj:`None`)
        output_language (str, optional): The language used for the agent's 
            output. If not specified, defaults to the system's language 
            setting. (default: :obj:`None`)
        tools (List[OpenAIFunction], optional): A list of available 
            :obj:`OpenAIFunction` instances for the agent. If not provided, 
            no tools are available. (default: :obj:`None`)
        response_terminators (List[ResponseTerminator], optional): A list of 
            :obj:`ResponseTerminator` instances that control when the agent 
            terminates its response. (default: :obj:`None`)

    """
    def __init__(self, system_message, model=None, memory=None, 
                 message_window_size=None, token_limit=None, 
                 output_language=None, tools=None, response_terminators=None):
        pass
```

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [Feature Request] Web toolkit
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [X] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

A toolkit that can achieve a certain degree of webpage (rendered) interaction, performs web-based tasks. (e.g. click elements and scrolling pages, open a given url, make a screenshot, use MLLM to understand the webpage content)

example task:
```
 ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† "Question": "Eva Draconis has a personal website which can be accessed on her YouTube page. What is the meaning of the only symbol seen in the top banner that has a curved line that isn't a circle or a portion of a circle? Answer without punctuation.",
  ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† "Final answer": "War is not here this is a land of peace",
  ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† "Annotation Metadata": {
  ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† "Steps": "1. By googling Eva Draconis youtube, you can find her channel.\n2. In her about section, she has written her website URL, orionmindproject.com.\n3. 1. Has the ability to process universal document types whether they are in urls or local files. It is supported by other bottom-level toolkits such as video toolkit, audio toolkit, etc. It uses GraphRAG to process raw text and query.

issues.title: [Feature Request] MCPToolkitManager Integration
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

The primary motivation behind introducing `MCPToolkitManager` is to offer a centralized configuration and connection management for handling multiple MCP toolkits.

In situations where an application needs to interact with several MCP servers or tools concurrently, managing each `MCPToolkit` individually can become cumbersome. The `MCPToolkitManager` abstracts this complexity, providing an **easy-to-use** interface to manage multiple toolkits and initiate connections to all of them in parallel. 

This is particularly useful in **environments where multiple external tools or servers are used simultaneously**, enhancing the scalability and flexibility of the system.


### Solution

The `MCPToolkitManager` class simplifies the management of multiple MCPToolkit instances. It will provide a simple interface to:

- Initialize multiple toolkits.
- Manage multiple toolkits concurrently.
- Connect to several toolkits at the same time.
- The `connection()` context manager ensures that all toolkits are connected simultaneously.
- The `get_all_tools()` method aggregates tools from all connected toolkits, offering a unified list of tools for use.

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [BUG] QWEN-MAX eorror code 400 invalid_parameter_error  role "tool" must be a response to a preceeding message with "tool_calls".'
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have read the documentation <https://camel-ai.github.io/camel/camel.html>.
- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### What version of camel are you using?

0.2.38

### System information

  File "D:\Program Files\Python\Python311\Lib\site-packages\camel\agents\chat_agent.py", line 595, in step
    response = self._get_model_response(
               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "D:\Program Files\Python\Python311\Lib\site-packages\camel\agents\chat_agent.py", line 795, in _get_model_response
    raise ModelProcessingError(
camel.models.model_manager.ModelProcessingError: Unable to process messages: the only provided model did not run successfully. Error: Error code: 400 - {'error': {'code': 'invalid_parameter_error', 'param': None, 'message': '<400> InternalError.Algo.InvalidParameter: messages with role "tool" must be a response to a preceeding message with "tool_calls".', 'type': 'invalid_request_error'}, 'id': 'chatcmpl-eb083945-3325-924f-973d-63f047d4f54a', 'request_id': 'eb083945-3325-924f-973d-63f047d4f54a'}

### Problem description

When calling tools through function calls, if the message for calling the tool and the message after calling the tool have the same timestamp, the order may become disordered.

In the **chat_agent.py** file, within the def _record_tool_calling function:

self.update_memory(assist_msg, OpenAIBackendRole.ASSISTANT)

self.update_memory(func_msg, OpenAIBackendRole.FUNCTION)

Two ContextRecord objects are created, both having the same timestamp, but the second ContextRecord has a higher score than the first one.

According to the sorting logic in the create_context function of the ScoreBasedContextCreator class in **score_based.py** , the second message is sorted before the first message.

This can cause memory confusion, and when calling the Qwen model, it may result in an error.

### Reproducible example code

from camel.agents import ChatAgent
from camel.configs import QwenConfig
from camel.toolkits import (
    SearchToolkit,
    # MathToolkit,
    # GoogleMapsToolkit,
    # TwitterToolkit,
    # WeatherToolkit,
    # RetrievalToolkit,
    # TwitterToolkit,
    # SlackToolkit,
    # LinkedInToolkit,
    # RedditToolkit,
)
from camel.messages import BaseMessage
from camel.models import ModelFactory
from camel.types import ModelPlatformType, ModelType
import os
from camel.toolkits import FunctionTool

# Prompt for the API key securely
qwen_api_key = os.environ.get('QWEN_KEY')
os.environ["QWEN_API_KEY"] = qwen_api_key
os.environ["DEEPSEEK_API_KEY"] = "xx"


def add(a: int, b: int) -> int:
    r"""Adds two numbers.

    Args:
        a (int): The first number to be added.
        b (int): The second number to be added.

    Returns:
        integer: The sum of the two numbers.
    """
    return a + b

def sub(a: int, b: int) -> int:
    r"""Do subtraction between two numbers.

    Args:
        a (int): The minuend in subtraction.
        b (int): The subtrahend in subtraction.

    Returns:
        integer: The result of subtracting :obj:`b` from :obj:`a`.
    """
    return a - b

MATH_FUNCS: list[FunctionTool] = [
    FunctionTool(func) for func in [add, sub]
]

tools_list = [
    # *MathToolkit().get_tools(),
    #*SearchToolkit().get_tools(),
    *MATH_FUNCS,
]

# Set up the model
model = ModelFactory.create(
    model_platform=ModelPlatformType.QWEN,
    model_type=ModelType.QWEN_MAX,
    model_config_dict=QwenConfig(temperature=0.0).as_dict(), # [Optional] the config for model
)

# Set message for the assistant
assistant_sys_msg =  """‰Ω†ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï∞Â≠¶Â∞èËÉΩÊâãÔºåÊìÖÈïøÂêÑÁßçËÆ°ÁÆó."""


# Set the agent
agent = ChatAgent(
    assistant_sys_msg,
    model=model,
    tools=tools_list
)

# Set prompt for the search task
prompt_search = ("""When was University of Oxford set up""")
# Set prompt for the calculation task
prompt_calculate = ("""Assume now is 2024 in the Gregorian calendar, University of Oxford was set up in 1096, estimate the current age of University of Oxford""")

# Convert the two prompt as message that can be accepted by the Agent
#user_msg_search = BaseMessage.make_user_message(role_name="User", content=prompt_search)
user_msg_calculate = BaseMessage.make_user_message(role_name="User", content=prompt_calculate)

# Get response
#assistant_response_search = agent.step(user_msg_search)
assistant_response_calculate = agent.step(user_msg_calculate)

#print(assistant_response_search.info)

print(assistant_response_calculate.info)

### Traceback

```pytb

```

### Expected behavior

_No response_

### Additional context

issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)

3.10.11 (tags/v3.10.11:7d4cc5a, Apr  5 2023, 00:38:17) [MSC v.1929 64 bit (AMD64)] win32
0.2.37

### Problem description

In `ChatAgent.astep()`,
```
            response = await self._aget_model_response(
                openai_messages,
                num_tokens,
                response_format,
                self._get_full_tool_schemas(),
            )

            if self.single_iteration:
                break

            if tool_call_requests := response.tool_call_requests:
                # Process all tool calls
                for tool_call_request in tool_call_requests:
                    if (
                        tool_call_request.tool_name
                        in self._external_tool_schemas
                    ):
                        if external_tool_call_requests is None:
                            external_tool_call_requests = []
                        external_tool_call_requests.append(tool_call_request)

                    tool_call_record = await self._aexecute_tool(
                        tool_call_request
                    )
                    tool_call_records.append(tool_call_record)

                # If we found an external tool call, break the loop
                if external_tool_call_requests:
                    break

                # If we're still here, continue the loop
                continue

            break
```
I think that 
```
            if self.single_iteration:
                break
```
should after the tool excute.
