issues.title: [Feature Request] Integrate Prolog into Camel Tools
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

Prolog is integrated with Python via Pyswip, however, it requires run-time dependencies of Prolog engine.

The current implementation uses Pyswip to integrate Prolog with Python. However, this creates a runtime dependency on the SWI-Prolog engine, which must be installed on the host system. Users encounter errors like:

```bash
ImportError: libswipl.so.8: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

or on macOS:
```bash
ImportError: dlopen(/usr/local/lib/python3.11/site-packages/pyswip/core/_pyswip.cpython-311-darwin.so, 0x0002): 
  tried: '/usr/local/lib/libswipl.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/lib/libswipl.dylib' (no such file)
```

This is a common issue with Python packages that rely on external system libraries (e.g., OpenCV, PyAudio). Simply installing via pip/poetry is insufficient as the system-level dependencies must be manually installed.

## Proposed Solution: Docker-based Code Execution

### Architecture Overview
1. Create a Docker container with all required dependencies
2. Implement a code execution service that:
   - Accepts Prolog code and input
   - Runs the code in an isolated container
   - Returns the results
3. Add a fallback mechanism for local execution



### Solution

_No response_

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [Feature Request] Sliding window for VectorRetriever
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

Currently, VectorRetriever retrieves results based on exact query matches without considering contextual continuity for long documents. This limitation makes it difficult to retrieve semantically relevant information that spans multiple chunks, leading to incomplete or disjointed retrieval results.

For example, when dealing with long-form documents, a relevant answer may span multiple adjacent chunks, but the current retrieval method does not account for this, causing loss of information. A sliding window approach would improve retrieval accuracy by ensuring overlapping context between chunks.


### Solution

Introduce a sliding window mechanism for VectorRetriever, where:
- Each chunk overlaps with the next by a configurable token/window size
- This ensures semantic continuity and better retrieval relevance
- It can be implemented as an optional parameter (window_size) in the VectorRetriever configuration

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.title: [Feature Request] Rejecting Instruction Preferences (RIP)
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation
This paper proposes a method to enhance model performance by evaluating data integrity, termed *Rejecting Instruction Preferences (RIP)*. The approach is based on the hypothesis that low-quality input prompts lead to high variance and low-quality responses. By measuring the quality of rejected responses and the reward gap between chosen and rejected preference pairs, RIP filters out suboptimal prompts. The RIP method has demonstrated significant improvements in model performance across multiple benchmarks.
so we may need to reproduce this paperÔºöhttps://arxiv.org/abs/2501.18578

issues.title: [Feature Request] a dev team that use workforce„ÄÅhuman in loop„ÄÅdeepsearch
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

A complete development team usually includes the following roles:

1. Project Management Category

‚ó¶ Project Manager (PM): Responsible for the planning, organization, coordination, and control of the entire project, ensuring that the project is completed on time, within quality standards, and within budget. Coordinate the work among team members and communicate and coordinate with external customers or other departments.

‚ó¶ Project Coordinator: Assist the project manager in project management work, mainly responsible for following up the project progress, coordinating resources, organizing and reporting project documents, etc., to ensure the smooth progress of all tasks in the project.

2. Development Category

‚ó¶ Developer (Dev): Implement software or system coding according to project requirements, including different directions such as front-end developers, back-end developers, and mobile developers. They are responsible for translating design documents into executable code.

‚ó¶ Software Architect: Responsible for designing the overall architecture of the software system, formulating technical solutions and making technology selections, ensuring the scalability, stability, and performance of the system, and guiding the development team in technical implementation.

‚ó¶ Algorithm Engineer: Mainly responsible for researching, designing, and implementing various algorithms to solve specific business problems or optimize system performance, such as machine learning algorithm engineers and data mining algorithm engineers.

‚ó¶ Security Engineer: Focus on ensuring the security of software systems and networks, conducting security vulnerability detection, preventing network attacks, and formulating security strategies and measures.

3. Testing Category

‚ó¶ Test Engineer: Develop test plans and test cases, conduct functional, performance, compatibility, and other aspects of testing on software products, discover and record defects and problems in the software, and ensure that the software quality meets the requirements.

‚ó¶ Test Manager: Responsible for the management of the entire testing team and the planning, organization, and execution of testing projects, coordinating testing resources, formulating testing strategies, and ensuring the efficient progress of testing work and the achievement of testing objectives.

4. Design Category

‚ó¶ Product Designer: From the perspective of user experience, conduct product interface design, interaction design, etc., focusing on the interaction process and visual effects between users and products, and improving the usability and user satisfaction of the product.

‚ó¶ User Experience Designer (UX Designer): Through methods such as user research and competitive product analysis, provide optimization suggestions for the functional and process design of products, conduct user testing and collect feedback, so as to continuously improve the user experience of the product.

5. Operation and Maintenance Category

‚ó¶ Operations Engineer: Responsible for the deployment, maintenance, and operation of software systems, ensuring the stable operation of the system, including server management, network configuration, data backup and recovery, troubleshooting and handling of failures, etc.

‚ó¶ DevOps Engineer: Combine development and operation and maintenance work, and through automated tools and technologies, achieve continuous integration, continuous deployment, and automated operation and maintenance of software, improving software delivery efficiency and operation and maintenance quality.


### Solution

_No response_

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

### Motivation

In dynamic and unfamiliar environments, large models and robots often face a common problem: making overly confident yet incorrect predictions. A team of researchers from Princeton University and Google DeepMind addressed this issue by introducing the¬†[KnowNo](https://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01928v2) framework. This system helps robots recognize when they‚Äôre uncertain and allows them to ask for help from humans when necessary, using a concept called¬†conformal prediction (CP).

python -m sglang.launch_server --model-path /.lmstudio/models/lmstudio-community/DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-32B-GGUF/DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-32B-Q4_K_M.gguf --tp 8 --enable-p2p-check --host 0.0.0.0 --port 30000 --trust-remote-code

### System information

from colorama import Fore
from camel.societies import RolePlaying
from camel.utils import print_text_animated
from camel.models import ModelFactory
from camel.types import ModelPlatformType
import os
import sys

# Set system encoding to UTF-8
sys.stdout.reconfigure(encoding='utf-8')

# Set environment variable for encoding
os.environ['PYTHONIOENCODING'] = 'utf-8'

model = ModelFactory.create(
    model_platform=ModelPlatformType.SGLANG,
    model_type="/hpc2hdd/home/xhe989/.lmstudio/models/lmstudio-community/DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-32B-GGUF/DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-32B-Q4_K_M.gguf",
    model_config_dict={"temperature": 0.6, "max_tokens": 14096},
    api_key="sglang",
)

def main(model=model, chat_turn_limit=50) -> None:
    task_prompt = "Develop a trading bot for the stock market"  # Set task objective
    role_play_session = RolePlaying(
        assistant_role_name="Python Programmer",  # Set AI assistant role
        assistant_agent_kwargs=dict(model=model),
        user_role_name="Stock Trader",  # Set user role
        user_agent_kwargs=dict(model=model),
        task_prompt=task_prompt,
        with_task_specify=True,
        task_specify_agent_kwargs=dict(model=model),
       
    )

    print(
        Fore.GREEN
        + f"AI Assistant System Message:\n{role_play_session.assistant_sys_msg}\n"
    )
    print(
        Fore.BLUE + f"AI User System Message:\n{role_play_session.user_sys_msg}\n"
    )

    print(Fore.YELLOW + f"Original Task Prompt:\n{task_prompt}\n")
    print(
        Fore.CYAN
        + "Specified Task Prompt:"
        + f"\n{role_play_session.specified_task_prompt}\n"
    )
    print(Fore.RED + f"Final Task Prompt:\n{role_play_session.task_prompt}\n")

    n = 0
    input_msg = role_play_session.init_chat()
    while n < chat_turn_limit:
        n += 1
        assistant_response, user_response = role_play_session.step(input_msg)

        if assistant_response.terminated:
            print(
                Fore.GREEN
                + (
                    "AI Assistant terminated. Reason: "
                    f"{assistant_response.info['termination_reasons']}."
                )
            )
            break
        if user_response.terminated:
            print(
                Fore.GREEN
                + (
                    "AI User terminated. "
                    f"Reason: {user_response.info['termination_reasons']}."
                )
            )
            break

        print_text_animated(
            Fore.BLUE + f"AI User:\n\n{user_response.msg.content}\n"
        )
        print_text_animated(
            Fore.GREEN + "AI Assistant:\n\n"
            f"{assistant_response.msg.content}\n"
        )

        if "CAMEL_TASK_DONE" in user_response.msg.content:
            break

        input_msg = assistant_response.msg

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

issues.body:

### Questions

Im trying to get groq working with a tool call but it returns an empty response.

Sample snippet
```
tools_list = [
    *MathToolkit().get_tools(),
    *SearchToolkit().get_tools(),
]

model = ModelFactory.create(
    model_platform = ModelPlatformType.GROQ,
    model_type = ModelType.GROQ_MIXTRAL_8_7B
)

# Set message for the assistant
assistant_sys_msg =  """You are a helpful assistant to do search task."""


# Set the agent
agent = ChatAgent(
    assistant_sys_msg,
    model=model,
    tools=tools_list
)

# Set prompt for the search task
prompt_search = ("""When was University of Oxford set up""")
# Set prompt for the calculation task
prompt_calculate = ("""Assume now is 2024 in the Gregorian calendar, University of Oxford was set up in 1096, estimate the current age of University of Oxford""")

# Convert the two prompt as message that can be accepted by the Agent
user_msg_search = BaseMessage.make_user_message(role_name="User", content=prompt_search)
user_msg_calculate = BaseMessage.make_user_message(role_name="User", content=prompt_calculate)

# Get response
assistant_response_search = agent.step(user_msg_search)
assistant_response_calculate = agent.step(user_msg_calculate)
```

comments.body: What is the default `50`?

comments.author: zoezyn
comments.body: @Wendong-Fan Hi, I'd like to work on this issue. I didn't find where the default context window setting is (is it only 50)?  Probably need some guidance though.

comments.body: Hey @lightaime @zoezyn , apologies for the confusion. In CAMEL, we don't set a default value for `message_window_size`. The value 50 is just an example that the user could choose to set

issues.title: [Feature Request] Adding timeout for individual function call
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

When I adopt a ChatAgent equipped with a function call (such as mathToolkits) to solve a series of math problems, sometimes the questions are very hard and thus the function is called for a long time, which causes the job to crash due to reaching the time-limit. 

### Solution

It would be beneficial for Camel to add a time-out for an individual function call so that it could kill the function if no respond within a certain time limit.

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [X] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)

### Motivation
further enhancement based on https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/pull/1142

1. Update dynamic tool calling mechanism.
2. Implement exception handling for memory overflow (refer to: [GitHub PR discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/pull/1142#discussion_r1868376503)).
3. Relocate tool calling logic from the agent level to the model level.
4. Add check for the necessity of tool calling to help exiting while loop in `.step`.
5. decouple the structure output from the agent somehow, like the tool calling mechanism.
6. Asynchronous support (Model and Agent level).
7. Enable streaming output.

issues.title: [Feature Request] Improve JSON Dump in SelfInstructPipeline for Non-ASCII Character Readability
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

Currently, in the SelfInstructPipeline class, when using json.dump to write data to a JSON file, non-ASCII characters (including Chinese characters and other special characters) are encoded as Unicode. This encoding reduces the human readability of the JSON output.

```json
    {
        "id": "machine_task_1",
        "instruction": "Create a short story involving a mysterious clock that only appears on full moon nights and disappears at dawn, exploring themes of time and destiny.",
        "is_classification": false,
        "instances": [
            {
                "input": "",
                "output": "\u5728\u4e00\u4e2a\u6708\u5149\u768e\u6d01\u7684\u591c\u665a\uff0c\u5c0f\u9547\u4e0a\u7684\u5c45\u6c11\u4eec\u7a81\u7136\u53d1\u73b0\u5e7f\u573a\u4e0a\u591a\u4e86\u4e00\u5ea7\u53e4\u8001\u7684\u949f\u3002\u8fd9\u5ea7\u949f\u53ea\u6709\u5728\u6ee1\u6708\u4e4b\u591c\u624d\u4f1a\u51fa\u73b0\uff0c\u5e76\u4e14\u4f1a\u5728\u9ece\u660e\u7684\u7b2c\u4e00\u7f15\u9633\u5149\u4e2d\u6d88\u5931\u65e0\u8e2a\u3002\u9547\u4e0a\u7684\u8001\u4eba\u8bf4\uff0c\u8fd9\u662f\u4e00\u5ea7\u795e\u79d8\u7684\u65f6\u949f\uff0c\u5b83\u8bb0\u5f55\u7740\u547d\u8fd0\u7684\u8f68\u8ff9\u3002\u5e74\u8f7b\u7684\u60c5\u4fa3\u739b\u4e3d\u548c\u6c64\u59c6\u51b3\u5b9a\u63a2\u7d22\u8fd9\u4e2a\u8c1c\u56e2\u3002\u4ed6\u4eec\u53d1\u73b0\u6bcf\u5f53\u949f\u58f0\u54cd\u8d77\uff0c\u5468\u56f4\u7684\u65f6\u95f4\u4f3c\u4e4e\u53d8\u5f97\u7f13\u6162\uff0c\u4eff\u4f5b\u6574\u4e2a\u4e16\u754c\u90fd\u5728\u503e\u542c\u3002\u4e00\u5929\u591c\u91cc\uff0c\u5f53\u949f\u58f0\u518d\u6b21\u54cd\u8d77\uff0c\u739b\u4e3d\u610f\u8bc6\u5230\u5979\u4e0e\u6c64\u59c6\u76f8\u9047\u7684\u90a3\u4e00\u523b\u6b63\u662f\u949f\u58f0\u6572\u54cd\u7684\u65f6\u523b\u3002\u5979\u5f00\u59cb\u76f8\u4fe1\uff0c\u8fd9\u5ea7\u795e\u79d8\u7684\u949f\u662f\u547d\u8fd0\u7684\u6307\u5f15\u8005\uff0c\u800c\u5979\u548c\u6c64\u59c6\u7684\u547d\u8fd0\u65e9\u5df2\u88ab\u6ce8\u5b9a\u3002"
            },
            {
                "input": "",
                "output": "\u6770\u514b\u662f\u4e00\u4f4d\u5386\u53f2\u5b66\u5bb6\uff0c\u4ed6\u542c\u8bf4\u4e86\u5173\u4e8e\u795e\u79d8\u65f6\u949f\u7684\u4f20\u8bf4\u3002\u6ee1\u6708\u4e4b\u591c\uff0c\u4ed6\u72ec\u81ea\u4e00\u4eba\u6765\u5230\u5e7f\u573a\uff0c\u7b49\u5f85\u7740\u65f6\u949f\u7684\u51fa\u73b0\u3002\u7ec8\u4e8e\uff0c\u5728\u6708\u5149\u4e0b\uff0c\u90a3\u5ea7\u53e4\u8001\u7684\u949f\u7f13\u7f13\u663e\u73b0\u3002\u6770\u514b\u8d70\u8fd1\u4ed4\u7ec6\u89c2\u5bdf\uff0c\u53d1\u73b0\u949f\u9762\u4e0a\u523b\u6709\u590d\u6742\u7684\u7b26\u53f7\u548c\u6570\u5b57\u3002\u4ed6\u8bd5\u56fe\u89e3\u8bfb\u8fd9\u4e9b\u7b26\u53f7\uff0c\u5374\u53d1\u73b0\u81ea\u5df1\u9677\u5165\u4e86\u4e00\u4e2a\u65f6\u95f4\u5faa\u73af\u4e2d\u3002\u6bcf\u5f53\u591c\u5e55\u964d\u4e34\uff0c\u4ed6\u4f1a\u56de\u5230\u90a3\u4e2a\u6ee1\u6708\u4e4b\u591c\uff0c\u91cd\u65b0\u9762\u5bf9\u540c\u6837\u7684\u6311\u6218\u3002\u7ecf\u8fc7\u65e0\u6570\u6b21\u5c1d\u8bd5\uff0c\u6770\u514b\u7ec8\u4e8e\u89e3\u5f00\u4e86\u949f\u7684\u79d8\u5bc6\uff0c\u4ed6\u610f\u8bc6\u5230\u81ea\u5df1\u7684\u547d\u8fd0\u65e9\u5df2\u88ab\u5199\u5b9a\uff0c\u800c\u8fd9\u5ea7\u795e\u79d8\u7684\u949f\u53ea\u662f\u65f6\u95f4\u7684\u89c1\u8bc1\u8005\u3002"
            }
        ]
    }
```

### Solution

Modify the json.dump function within SelfInstructPipeline to set the ensure_ascii parameter to False. This change will allow non-ASCII characters to be directly written to the JSON file, enhancing readability.

### Alternatives

_No response_

_No response_

issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

### What version of camel are you using?

0.2.16

### System information

I use the Google Colab to install CAMEL

### Problem description

The bug report is as follows:

ImportError                               Traceback (most recent call last)
/tmp/ipykernel_51341/1116332117.py in <cell line: 0>()
      2 from camel.configs import ChatGPTConfig
      3 from camel.models import ModelFactory
----> 4 from camel.toolkits import SemanticScholarToolkit
      5 from camel.types import ModelPlatformType, ModelType
      6 

ImportError: cannot import name 'SemanticScholarToolkit' from 'camel.toolkits' (/usr/local/lib/python3.11/dist-packages/camel/toolkits/__init__.py)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/42bfffc2-f163-4f19-a6a0-391ee5293624)

### Reproducible example code

The Python snippets:

```python

!pip install 'camel-ai[all]'

import os

os.environ["OPENAI_API_KEY"] = "sk-xxx"
os.environ["OPENAI_API_BASE_URL"] = "https://xxx"

from camel.agents import ChatAgent
from camel.configs import ChatGPTConfig
from camel.models import ModelFactory
from camel.toolkits import SemanticScholarToolkit
from camel.types import ModelPlatformType, ModelType

# Define the model, here in this case we use gpt-40
model = ModelFactory.create(
    model_platform=ModelPlatformType.OPENAI,
    model_type=ModelType.GPT_4O_MINI,
    model_config_dict=ChatGPTConfig(temperature=0.0).as_dict(),
)

sys_msg = "You are a helpful assistant"

# Initialize a toolkit
toolkit = SemanticScholarToolkit()

# Get list of tools
tools = toolkit.get_tools()

# Initialize a ChatAgent with your custom tools
camel_agent = ChatAgent(
    system_message=sys_msg,
    model=model,
    tools=tools,
)

# Description of the added tools
usr_msg = "Describe the tools you've added"

response = camel_agent.step(usr_msg)
print(response.msgs[0].content)

# Description of the added tools
'''
1. *fetch_paper_data_title*: This tool fetches a single paper
based on its title. You can specify which fields to include in
the response, such as the abstract, authors, year, citation
count, and more.

2. *fetch_paper_data_id*: Similar to the previous tool,
this one retrieves a single paper but uses a paper ID instead
of the title. It also allows for specifying the fields to
include in the response.

3. *fetch_bulk_paper_data*: This tool allows you to fetch
multiple papers at once based on a query that can include
various operators (like AND, OR, NOT). You can filter by
year and specify which fields to return.

4. *fetch_recommended_papers*: This tool provides recommendations for papers based on a list of positively
and negatively correlated paper IDs. You can specify the
fields to include in the response and limit the number
of papers returned.

5. *fetch_author_data*: This tool retrieves information
about authors based on their IDs. You can specify which
fields to include in the response, such as the author's name,
URL, paper count, h-index, and their papers.

These tools can be used individually or in combination to
gather comprehensive information about academic literature
and authors.
'''

issues.title: [BUG] Partitioning PDF File in VectorRetriever Due to Missing libmagic Dependency on Windows
issues.body:
When using VectorRetriever to import a PDF, the following warning appears:

c:\Users\SunTao\Desktop\camel-master\camel\loaders\unstructured_io.py:154: UserWarning: Failed to partition the file: local_data/camel_paper.pdf
  warnings.warn(f"Failed to partition the file: {input_path}")
After investigating, I found that the issue lies in the parse_file_or_url method of UnstructuredIO, which uses the partition method from unstructured.partition.auto. This method relies on the libmagic library. After installing python-magic-bin on my Windows system, the issue was resolved.

pip install python-magic-bin

Additional details:

Installed using poetry install -E all.

Camel version: 0.2.19.

System: Windows.

Python version: 3.12.4.


Reproducible example code

from camel.retrievers import VectorRetriever
from camel.types import StorageType
from camel.embeddings import SentenceTransformerEncoder

embedding_model=SentenceTransformerEncoder(model_name='intfloat/e5-large-v2')
vr = VectorRetriever(embedding_model= embedding_model)

from camel.storages.vectordb_storages import QdrantStorage

vector_storage = QdrantStorage(
    vector_dim=embedding_model.get_output_dim(),
    collection="demo_collection",
    path="storage_customized_run",
    collection_name="paper"
)


vr.process(
    content="local_data/camel_paper.pdf", 
    storage=vector_storage
)

issues.title: [Feature Request] More data format support
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [X] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [ ] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### Motivation

alignment data etc.. 

**Instruction Data**
Reference implemented in camel: https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/blob/master/camel/messages/conversion/alpaca.py

**Conversation Data**
Reference implemented in camel: https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/blob/master/camel/messages/conversion/conversation_models.py

**TODO:**

**Alignment Data**
Description: Scenarios that align the model's responses with human values, ethical guidelines, and desired behaviors, especially for handling sensitive topics.

example: https://huggingface.co/datasets/Magpie-Align/Magpie-Qwen2.5-Math-Pro-300K-v0.1


**Question and Answer (QA) Data**
Description: Pairs of questions and their corresponding answers to help the model generate accurate responses to various queries.
```
{
  "question": "What is the capital city of Australia?",
  "answer": "The capital city of Australia is Canberra."
}
```

**Code Data**
Description: Code snippets paired with descriptions or requirements, essential for training models to understand, generate, and debug code in various programming languages.
```
{
  "description": "Write a Python function that returns the factorial of a number.",
  "code": "def factorial(n):\n    if n == 0:\n        return 1\n    else:\n        return n * factorial(n-1)"
}
```

**Classification Data**
Description: Texts labeled with specific categories or tags, useful for tasks like sentiment analysis, topic classification, or spam detection.
```
{
  "text": "I absolutely loved the new movie! The storyline was gripping and the characters were well-developed.",
  "label": "Positive Sentiment"
}
```

**Entity Recognition Data**
Description: Texts with annotated entities such as names, dates, locations, etc., training models to identify and categorize key information within the text.
```
{
  "text": "Apple Inc. was founded by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak in Cupertino, California, in 1976.",
  "entities": [
    {"entity": "Apple Inc.", "type": "Organization"},
    {"entity": "Steve Jobs", "type": "Person"},
    {"entity": "Steve Wozniak", "type": "Person"},
    {"entity": "Cupertino, California", "type": "Location"},
    {"entity": "1976", "type": "Date"}
  ]
}
```

### Solution

_No response_

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

issues.title: [Feature Request] General Deduplication Utility for String-based Data.
issues.body:
### Required prerequisites

- [x] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [x] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

## **Motivation / Background**

We have observed frequent duplicates or near-duplicates across different modules, 
such as user inputs, knowledge graph nodes, or text-based data in our pipeline. 

This results in:

- Increased confusion and potential redundancy in search or retrieval,
- Larger storage requirements,
- Potential performance degradation over time.

Previously, we had a specialized deduplication utility targeting `Node` objects (FinDKG project),
but this approach does not generalize well to other text-based data.

## **Proposal**

Introduce a `deduplication.py` module with more flexible deduplication related functions. 

- [ ] `deduplication_internally`
- [ ] `deduplication_externally`

Key features and improvements:

1. **Works with strings**: Instead of requiring `Node` objects, we now accept lists of raw strings.
2. **Optional embeddings parameter**: 
   - Users can supply a `BaseEmbedding` instance from the Camel embedding library, 
     and the function will internally handle embeddings.
   - Alternatively, users can pass in precomputed embeddings directly if they have 
     their own embedding process or data is pre-embedded.
3. **Multiple strategies**:
   - Initially supports a `"top1"` strategy (i.e., find the highest similarity above threshold).
   - A future `"llm-supervise"` strategy will rely on an LLM to decide whether two 
     texts are duplicates, especially when borderline or semantic similarity is unclear. 
     (Currently not implemented, but planned.)

## **Example**

See the updated function `deduplicate_internally` in `deduplication.py`:
```python
def deduplicate_internally(
    texts: List[str],
    threshold: float = 0.65,
    embedding_instance: Optional[BaseEmbedding[str]] = None,
    embeddings: Optional[List[List[float]]] = None,
    strategy: Literal["top1", "llm-supervise"] = "top1",
) -> DeduplicationResult:
    ...
```
